title: 108_hr2432
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Paperwork and Regulatory Improvements Act of 2004". Congress established the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs (OIRA) in 1980 to reduce the paperwork burden on the public. In 2002, OIRA estimated the burden at 7.7 billion hours and $230 billion in cost, with the IRS responsible for 83% of it. Despite government goals to reduce paperwork, the burden increased from 1996 to 2001. In 2002, the paperwork burden on Americans increased, with the IRS imposing over 80% of it. The Office of Management and Budget needs to focus on identifying and reviewing IRS paperwork to reduce the burden. In 2000, researchers estimated Americans spend $843 billion annually to comply with Federal regulations. Congress should review major rules proposed by agencies, including regulatory alternatives and associated costs and benefits. In 2000, Congress established new responsibilities within the General Accounting Office to assist with the increasing costs and benefits of Federal rules and paperwork. Congress required the Office of Management and Budget to submit an annual report on the total costs and benefits of Federal rules, including their effects on the private sector and State and local governments. The Office of Management and Budget requires agencies to report on budget and paperwork burden estimates annually, but they are not required to estimate costs and benefits of agency rules and paperwork. Congress made this reporting requirement permanent in 2000 to help prepare the annual accounting statement under the Treasury and General Government Appropriations Act, 2001. SEC. 3. REDUCTION OF TAX PAPERWORK.

Section 3504 of title 44, United States Code, is amended to reduce the information collection burden on small businesses by identifying actions the Internal Revenue Service can take. This review will be included in the annual report for fiscal year 2006.

SEC. 4. REPEAL OF EXEMPTIONS FROM PAPERWORK REDUCTION ACT. SEC. 4. REPEAL OF EXEMPTIONS FROM PAPERWORK REDUCTION ACT, ETC. The Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 provisions are repealed, with an effective date 180 days after enactment. The Truth in Regulating Act of 2000 is amended to enhance Congressional responsibility for regulatory decisions by making permanent the authority to request regulatory analysis. This includes improvements to regulatory accounting. The Truth in Regulating Act of 2000 is amended to require agencies to submit information on regulations and paperwork to OMB annually for cost and benefit estimates. The Truth in Regulating Act of 2000 is amended to require agencies to submit information on regulations and paperwork to OMB annually for cost and benefit estimates. Section 624 of the Treasury and General Government Appropriations Act, 2001 is further amended to integrate OMB Accounting Statement and Report into the President's Budget, and a new section on Regulatory Budgeting is added to Chapter 11 of title 31, United States Code. The Truth in Regulating Act of 2000 is amended to require agencies to submit information on regulations and paperwork to OMB annually for cost and benefit estimates. A new section on Regulatory Budgeting is added to Chapter 11 of title 31, United States Code, which mandates the presentation of varying estimated levels of benefits and costs associated with regulatory alternatives under consideration by agencies. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is tasked with including this information in the accounting statement and report submitted to Congress for calendar year 2006. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is required to include a report on the study of regulatory budgeting in the accounting statement and report submitted to Congress for calendar year 2009. The report will assess the feasibility and advisability of incorporating a regulatory budget into the annual budget, describe any challenges faced during the study, and provide recommendations as deemed necessary by the President. The President may recommend proposed legislation on regulatory budgets. A new item is added to the table of sections in the chapter. Regulatory budgeting is introduced as a new concept in legislation.
